moves.1. d4: Reminder of the time limit - 40 moves in 90 minutes, plus 30 minutes if your time runs out before then, plus 30 second increment.
moves.1... Nf6: Again I was late for the start - 18 minutes this time - because of road works on the A41 near Chester.
moves.3. d5: I reply with the main line, heading for the Benoni group of openings. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benoni_Defense
moves.3... b5: A slight surprise, as he had played e7-e5 earlier in the tournament. I did see he had played this, the Benko Gambit, before. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benko_Gambit
moves.4. f3: Modern practice is to decline the gambit although this may not be the best way of declining it.
moves.6. Bxc4: Having lost time in arriving late, I played this quickly. My opponent pointed out afterwards that 6. Nc3 is more common.
moves.8... Be7: In many lines of the Benko the Bf8 goes to g7, but in this position I can throw in a queen check on e2 if he tries that.
moves.10. O-O:
I castle. Gouret, Thierry (2300) vs. Le Bourhis, Dominique (2050)  continued with O-O
10.	Ng3	Re8
11.	O-O	a6
12.	a4	Nbd7
13.	Re1	Ne5 which I think is better than what he played. The Gameknot game wwgia (1745) vs. hbking (2023) continued with Nbd7
11.	Ng3	Ne5
12.	b3	Qa5
13.	Bb2	Nxc4
14.	bxc4	Ba6 which I think is also better.
moves.10... Na6: Ganging up on the d pawn.
moves.11. Ng3: The natural square for the knight. I can also gang up on his d pawn with a knight to e4 and bishop to f4. On this square I am also restricting the development of his Bc8. I think white is doing OK here.
moves.12. Re1: Again, the natural place to put the rook.
moves.12... a6: Presumably to prevent my knight from going to b5 and maybe preparing to put his knight on b5 in some variations.
moves.13... g6: A somewhat drastic way of preventing Nf5. Black weakens his dark squares significantly. I should just play Bh6 here and double rooks on the e file and white is doing fine, or maybe Bg5, but....
moves.14. Rxe7: I thought I was winning back enough material.
moves.15. Bg5: With a horrible threat of Ne4.
moves.16. f4: I protect my bishop and attack his queen.
moves.16... Qd4+: When I sacrificed on e7 I considered 15...Qe5 and thought that 16. f4 won. I hadn't seen this queen check.
moves.19. Bxc3: I take back. A pawn for the exchange is not really enough, although converting it can be a problem.
moves.19... Bb7: This is a mistake. He should have played f5, keeping my knight out of his position.
moves.20. Ne4: Now if he takes on d4 I have a fork on f6 winning a piece. Plus 21. Nf6+ is a nasty threat.
moves.21. Bb3: With the idea of Rd1 and Bh4 attacking his knight with is protecting d6.
moves.23... Rf7: And his rook is sort of developed along the rank.
moves.24. Bb4: Attacking d6, again with the plan of Ba4 and Rd1, but it is too slow.
moves.24... a5: I hadn't expected this, but it looks good.
moves.26. Bc4: I have to keep on the d pawn.
moves.26... Ba6: being material up, he wants to exchange pieces.
moves.28. Rc1: I seize the c file, threatening Rc8
moves.29. Rc6: I offered a draw here, he declined.
moves.30. Kf2: I start to develop my king.
moves.32... Kf8: Not 32..... Ke7?? 33. Nc6+ winning! Now if I check again on e6 he just moves his king to e7 and I have run out of checks.
moves.36. Ke3: Another mistake by me. Simply Kf3, I am picking up his a pawn, and I am still in the game. This is the losing mistake.
moves.37... Rd7: He defends d6. Now when I played Ke3 I though that 38. Nf6 won. 38....Re7 is forced. I thought that after 39. Kf3 I was threatening both the rook on g2 and the pawn on d6, but he has Rd2 saving the rook and protecting d6.
moves.38. Nc7: So I tried this, with a similar threat. If 38....Rxc7 39. Bxd6+ although even there he has Rd7 winning.
moves.38... Re7+: But he chose this way to win.
moves.39. Kd3: I stop his Rg2 from protecting the d pawn.
moves.39... Kf7: But this simple move wins easily.
moves.40... Re4: I am just the exchange and a pawn down. I played it out, but really it is hopeless now. Further comment is unnecessary.
moves.41. Ra7+ Ke6 42. Nc3 Rxf4 43. Nxa4 Rxh2: He threatens mate on a2 and my bishop, so I resigned. Many thanks for reading please leave a comment or two and rate it on the star system to let me know how I am doing with my annotations. Until next time dear reader!

players: Charles L Higgie (1918) vs. Gareth Morris (2062)
